div.sent: There are various Media's of drawing paintings.
Such as-oil colour, water-colour etc.
The first material for drawing is paper, The papers are thick-thin, rough surfaced, smooth and shining.
The thick paper is called board.
Theseboards can also be found rough surfaced or smooth and of various kinds and colours.
The papers easily found for painting in Bangladesh are called Cartridge paper.
Cartridge paper are of two/three qualities.
The coloured cartridge paper is not milk-white, slightly dull-white.
The'pictures can be drawn with, pencils, pen-ink, water colours and pastels in this paper.
This paper is firstly used for drawings and paintings.
Slightlythick and white offset paper is good to draw with pen-ink and pencils.
It is not good for water colour painting.
The rough surfaced paper is neededfor water-colour.
The ordinary quality painting can be done in the rough-surfaced cartridge paper.
But for the water colour, the best paper is Hand-made paper.
It is not yet made in Bangladesh This paper is made in India mainly in Calcutta andits surrounding areas as a cottage industry (crafts).
The painting can bedone in this paper with pastal colour too.
The other papers which can be found in our Country are art-card, boox-board, paste-board and variousthick coloured papers.
The ordinary papers for writing and printing booksis called newsprint paper.
Art-card and art-paper is only fit for pen-ink and brush-ink paintings.
These papers are smooth and shining.
This paper, is suitable for improved printing.
Box-board is thick with one side white and smooth and another side gray or brown and slightly rough.
This paper is used to mount or frame Pictures.
It is interesting to paint with pastel on the gray side.
Paste-boardis thick and hard, the colour is deep brown or light brown.
It is possible topaint with pastel on it.
There are some papers which are used to bindbooks and to make packages, the artists some times use them to paint.
There are coloured papers which are of many colours and texturs-thin, rough, smooth.
The pictures can be drawn in many ways on these papers.
Some : artists make various kinds Of pictures with these papers by cutting, tearing and pasting.
The pictures which are made by cutting and tearing paper is called Collage-picture.
Pencil The pencil is a too] for drawing.
There is a kind of pencil which is used for writing and there are different kind of -pencils for drawing.
They are The hard leaded pencils are used for writing.
These pencils can not mark deeply on paper.
To get a dark effect 2B, 3B, 4B, 5B, and 6B are needed.
The leads of these pencils are soft and appear dark on the paper.
Many artists draw full pictures with pencils.
It is possible to draw a full Picture with 2B, 4B and 6B pencils.
We write with a pen.
A picture can be drawn with a pen too.
A beautiful picture can be drawn with a fountain pen with black ink in it.
The Pictures can be drawn with other Coloured ink too.
But the artists give priority to black ink.
There is a special kind of black ink, usually, which is called Chinese ink.
But it is called Indian ink too.
Many artists draw pictures with brush and ink.
But there are differences between brush-ink-pictures and pen-ink pictures.
The black and white or Coloured pictures can be drawn with a pen, named felt-pen or signature-pen.
It is possible to draw the same Pictures with a pen called marker-pen.
Shilpacharya liked to draw with the khag's pen.
Many of his famous drawings were drawn this way.
The village children, can easily collect the Bamboo- twinges and khags.
The brush is another main tool for doing paintings.
Normally soft brushes are used for ink and water Colours; and relatively harder brushes used for oil and poster colours.
Various kinds and sizes of brushes are made according to colours, papers and canvases.
But the use of, brushes depends entirely on the wish and convenience of the artist.
Brushes are usually made from animals hair, sometimes they are synthetically made.
These are very thin brushes.
Board-Clip-Easel Different kinds of brushes for drawing Board-clips are necessary things for drawing a picture.
It is convenient to draw a picture by fixing a paper on a board with a board-clip.
Some artists keep this board on the floor under the hands and some keep on the table to draw the pictures.
Some draw pictures keeping this board on the easel.
On the other hand an easel is the most important thing to paint on the canvas.
It depends on the person or how the artists will draw and feel convenient and conformable.
Without colours one cannot think of drawing a picture.
If the pictures are drawn with pencils or ink these are considered as colours too.
But coloured pictures are considered to be drawn with various colours.
Colours are found in various ways.
Water colours are found in boxes, tubes the cakes in a box and powder colours.
Poster colours are found in glass-pots.
Though the poster colour is a different media from the water colour, yet paintings get the same effect as the paintings done with water colours.
The pictures can be painted mixing water with powder colours.
But, there will be another effect if the gum is mixed with water and powder colour.
There are three varieties of postar colours.
They are chalk-pastel, oil-pastel and wax- crayon.
These are found in colour boxes; various colours in the same box, like colored sticks to look at.
Chalk pastel is slightly soft as congealed powder colours.
It is needed to spray very carefully with one kind of permanent- transparent liquid thing on the painting to make it permanent.
Otherwise the painting will be faded if it is rubbed.
On the other hand, it is convenient to paint with oil-pastel and wax- crayon, which is make durable in nature.
The subject matters of paintings are available in our surroundings.
If you look at your surroundings you will see so many (countless) subjects in our nature, the way of living and environment.
There are zoos in the city.
There are many animals and birds in zoos.
The amusing gestures of birds and animals, their games, actions sleeping and many other poses may be the subjects of paintings.
2 Picture of Zainul Abedin on The crow.
Hasem khan's drawing The Buffaloes.
There are pet birds, goats, dogs, cats almost in every house of a village.
Many people like pet wild birds too.
There are pet animals and birds in the cities also.
These pet animals and birds may be the subject of paintings.
There are many famous paintings on birds and animals by renowned painters.
Shilpacharya Zainul Abedin used crows and cows as the subjects of his paintings.
Qumrul Hassan chose cows, elephants, horses, foxes, snakes and a variety of birds as the Subjects of his paintings.
Paintings can be on parents, friends, relatives, brothers-sisters, grandfathers, grand- mothers or any other person you admire.
The painters should have a clear conception on which subjects they will draw.
One who has never been in the village, never seen rivers and boats cann't draw a picture of a village.
He should know about the environment, the livelihood and life-style of the people, and think about the simple behavior of the village-people and the Subjects.
Then his imaginations and thinking Should be dealt out beautifully and attractively.
If the pictures are being drawn on the cities and parts, those should be observed minutely then the imaginations and thoughts can be expressed beautifully.
Drawings are bassed on one's own desire or pleasure.
The painter tries to draw simply whatever he thinks according to his convenience and comfort.
No rule is needed for children's Paintings.
It is enough if they can fill up the pictures with colours and lines as they think and wish.
There is no good result if the children are taught drawing and other rules of paintings.
The paintings do not become nice and lively.
You have drawn the Pictures that way simply and naturally in your childhood.
The pictures which are drawn by the children never will be as same as the paintings drawn by the elder- artists.
There is another characteristic and form in the child-art.
The cows, fishes, trees, people etc. have a child-like truant which are drawn by the children.
As the children grow up the mode of paintings change too.
You have been introduced a bit to the rules of simple drawings.
There will not be much change in class seven.
But you will have to practice more; the rules and the artistic skills are to he learnt thoroughly.
What you have to learn are forms, drawings with shapes, distance and proportion, light and shade, arranging subjects and using of calours.
Observe the houses, trees, boats, cars, horses, people, animals and birds which are in Our surroundings.
How do they look?
What are the real forms?
When the children are growing they wish to draw correctly the real form and shapes of the above mentioned objects.
For that reason, a few rules must be learnt.
It should be a habituated by practicing drawings again and again.
It can be observed that all things may be put in two or three shapes or forms.
These shapes are round- shaped, square shaped and triangle- shaped.
It is shown here through a few pictures.
Look at the pictures and whenever you wish to draw something, observe and try to understand it is fat, thin, round, square or triangle.
What will be the size of the boat in proportion to a man?
If there is a tree near by, then what should .be
the relative size of the tree?
All these things are to be considered to draw a picture properly.
The comparison in size or proportion of small and big things is to be shown properly.
Suppose there are three boats or many people.
Then the distance can be made perceptible in the painting.
Structure of almost everything around us is similar to any shape of a round triangular of rectangular home.
The light and shade has an important role in some pictures except line-drawing and designs.
The light and shade should be shown properly in the paintings.
It is natural to have shade and darkness against sun shine.
The shade of bright-sun is bright too.
In the afternoon the rays of the sun is soft.
The shadow is the same.
The sun sets in the evening that's why it is their dark.
The light and shade call be divided in three groups for drawing the pictures conveniently.
Hence a few common rules should he maintained to draw a beautiful picture.
But the main thing is that at first try to understand and observe minutely the Subject which you wish to draw.
Be easy and coverageous when you draw a picture.
Colour as you like, keep away any hesitation or fear.
Suppose the subject of a painting is a village house.
There are three tin-shade-houses, trees, family members, hens and ducks etc. these things are to be arranged properly and proportionately.
So the picture will look beautiful.
This is called the arrangement of the subject.
Not only the drawing but every subject should be arranged in such a way, that it will look beautiful.
Such as a village scene, birds, animals, a man, flowers etc.
A subject may be arranged in three or four ways, select the best one, draw that one and put colours and light and shade.
It cannot be said that use of colours can be learnt from books.
Because drawing a picture demands practice and training.
Be accustomed to the uses of various colours by colouring and drawing pictures again and again.
The Students will learn from the teachers how to colour properly in different ways.
You Certainly have known about the primary and secondary colours.
But it is again mentioned as a reminder.
By mixing primary colours with secondary colours the other necessary colours can be prepared.
But it is not possible to prepare milk white and black colours, mixing with other colours.
It is slightly possible to prepare a deep blackish colour.
Some pictures are painted with mixing colours with water.
These colours are called water-colour.
The water colours can be found in a box like square tablets.
Loose tablets can be found too.
But there are watercolours in the tubes like tooth paste.
It is easy to use these colours.
There is another colour named poster- colour, mostly like the paste, found in a glass bottle.
The poster colours can be used with water to paint a picture.
Though it is similar to the water-colour, its quality is different.
The water colour is transparent and thin.
It. cannot be covered putting one colour on another.
Due to its transparency, both the colours can he seen and another colour can be made.
With one poster colour, another colour can be covered completely.
The Poster colour is thicker and heavier than the water colour.
Usually both the water colour and the poster colour are used on papers.
The beautiful one should be drawn.
Blind Man's bluff : Poster and Water colour Drawn by Sanzeeda Fatema Shamma, age-12 drawing a picture with water colour.
The paintings may be drawn on thick cartridge papers which are available in our country.
It is possible for one to collect hand-made or other high-quality papers.
Cut one sheet of cartridge paper in the middle.
If you wish, you can cut it in smaller sizes.
You have to remember that, the papers can not be twisted/ wrenched.
The cutting must be nice.
Fix your paper on a hard board with a board-clip so that it may remain fully stretched.
Now keep the board on the floor or prop it against a support.
Take some clean water in a pot.
Keep a palette (a painter mixes his colours) or a few small white saucers, keep the tubes or poster colours beside you.
Now it is time to draw.
Before you start think about the subject you want to draw.
Suppose you will draw the sky, covered with black- white clouds.
Draw the picture of clouds marking very lightly with the pencil.
It is better not to rub with a rubber.
If it is rubbed too much, there will be unnecessary marks on the paper.
It will spoil the picture.
Moist the paper with a piece of cloth or a broad brush before applying the colours.
Wait for a few minutes for the paper to dry a bit that.
Then take the colours on the saucers.
The brown colour is to be taken too.
Mix the brown and blue colours with water and apply that on the half-wet paper very lightly.
The colours should be applied from the top of the paper.
The brush should he used from left to right.
The colours will flow like the water.
Finish your wash quickly taking off the flowing colours.
Leave out the white parts of the clouds while you give the wash with blue-brown colours.
That means white parts of the paper will remain white.
Then wait for a while.
When the paper becomes lightly dried, then begin to colour the black parts of the clouds.
Prepare sufficient colours with blue - black and black - brown for this in different saucers.
Then apply the slight-light blue-black colours on the black parts of the clouds according to your drawing.
Then apply black- brown colours on some of the parts which you want to show darker.
After applying the colours on the wet paper and wet-colours, the effect will be the black clouds like the wet sky of a rainy-day.
Now apply very light black-brown colours on the white parts of the clouds where necessary to look shaded.
Your painting is complete now.
A simple method is discussed here.
A picture with water colour can be done-in a very short time in this way.
But various colours will be needed according to the subjects.
There will he differences of colours and more time will be needed for light and shade.
Wax or oil-pastel and chalk-pastel are a kind of Coloured sticks.
The painting is done by Rubbing these coloured-sticks on the papers.
There is no need of mixing the water, oil or gum with these colours.
But the liquid-fixative-mixture-spray is used for the chalk-pastel to make it permanent.
Because it is very soft after painting if it is moved the colours may he wiped out or may fall.
In the same way the liquid spray is used for paintings which are drawn with charcoal, to make them permanent.
Then these paintings may last long.
This liquid fixative can be found in a bottle in a shop, where colours are sold.
Usually oil colour is found in a tube.
The painting is done by mixing linseed oil and tarpeen with this colour.
The painting is done on thick canvas, hard board and a plank of wood.
The paper is made specially for oil colour paintings.
But the canvas made of cloth is the best for oil-colour-paintings.
The painting should be done in the media of oil colours in class seven and later for two to three years.
It is better to paint with oil colours after some experience with water-colours and pastel-colours.
So the paintings and other crafts should be done as many times as possible.
It is good to learn these from the teachers, directly.
Then it may be learnt thoroughly.
The Students should be attentive as well as the guardians Should give much importance to the Subject also.
